metadata.title: Ecological risk assessment of nano-enabled pesticides: A perspective on problem formulation

Perspective
Ecological risk assessment of nano-enabled pesticides: A perspective on problem formulation
Glen W Walker, Rai S Kookana, Natalie E Smith, Melanie Kah, Casey Doolette, Philip Reeves, Wess Lovell, Darren J Anderson, Terence W Turney, and Divina A Navarro
J. Agric. Food Chem., Just Accepted Manuscript • DOI: 10.1021/acs.jafc.7b02373 • Publication Date (Web): 16 Aug 2017
Downloaded from http://pubs.acs.org on August 16, 2017

Ecological risk assessment of nano-enabled pesticides: 1 A perspective on problem formulation 2
3
Glen W. Walker, a Rai S. Kookana,* b Natalie E. Smith, a Melanie Kah, c Casey L. Doolette, a 4
Philip Reeves, d Wess Lovell, e Darren J. Anderson, e Terence W. Turney f,g and Divina A. 5 Navarro b 6
7 a Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy, GPO Box 787, 8 Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia 9
b Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), PMB 2, Glen 10 Osmond, SA 5064, Australia 11 c University of Vienna, Department of Environmental Geosciences and Environmental 12 Science Research Network, Althanstrasse 14, UZA2, 1090 Vienna, Austria 13 d Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA), Canberra, ACT 2604, 14 Australia 15 e Vive Crop Protection, 112 College St., Toronto, Ontario, Canada, M5G1L6 16 f Sonic Essentials Pty Ltd, P.O. Box 258, Mooroopna, Victoria 3629, Australia 17 g Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Monash University, Clayton 3800, 18 Victoria, Australia 19
20 * Author to whom correspondence should be directed 21 Rai Kookana 22 CSIRO Land and Water 23 Email: Rai.Kookana@csiro.au 24
Page 1 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
2
ABSTRACT 25 Plant protection products containing nanomaterials that alter the functionality or risk profile 26 of active ingredients (nano-enabled pesticides) promise many benefits over conventional 27 pesticide products. These benefits may include improved formulation characteristics, easier 28 application, better targeting of pest species, increased efficacy, lower application rates, and 29 enhanced environmental safety. After many years of research and development, nano-enabled 30 pesticides are starting to make their way onto the market. The introduction of this technology 31 raises a number of issues for regulators, including: how does the ecological risk assessment 32 of nano-enabled pesticide products differ from that of conventional plant protection products? 33 In this paper, a group drawn from regulatory agencies, academia, research and the 34 agrochemicals industry offers a perspective on relevant considerations pertaining to the 35 problem formulation phase of the ecological risk assessment of nano-enabled pesticides. 36
37 Keywords: Nanopesticides; Agrochemicals; Nanotechnology; Problem Formulation; Risk 38 Assessment 39
Page 2 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
3
INTRODUCTION 40 Nanotechnology is being harnessed to develop new pharmaceutical drugs 41
(Nanomedicines) 1 as well as agrochemical products (Nanofertilisers and Nanopesticides). 2-5 42 These new medicines and agrochemicals exploit the properties of materials with dimensions 43 on the nanoscale (the size range of approximately 1 nm to 100 nm), which can display very 44 different or additional physical, chemical and biological properties compared to the properties 45 of the bulk materials. The application of nanotechnology in agriculture presents significant 46 new opportunities for developing more effective fertilisers and pesticides that may also have 47 reduced impacts on the environment. 48 There are a variety of possible ways in which nanotechnology may be used to produce 49 new pesticide products. There are inert ingredients used in conventional formulations of 50 pesticides that exist in a nanoscale form, and these nanoscale inert ingredients have been 51 incorporated into a range of crop protection products. Examples include nanoscale titania as a 52 UV blocker and whitener; nanoscale silica or clays as a rheology modifier; and many 53 nanoscale polymers are used as surfactants. There are also microemulsion-type solvent based 54 pesticides on the market that may be considered nano-enabled as many contain oil droplets 55 with significant populations < 100 nm. In most cases, these products have a long history of 56 safe use. 57 There is growing interest in more deliberate applications of nanotechnology in the 58 development of new plant protection products. 6 Dendrimer technology is being applied to a 59 number of a.i.s to develop nano-enabled pesticides with enhanced efficacy and some products 60 are in an advanced stage of development. 7 Some products utilising nanopolymers as carriers 61 for targeted delivery of pesticides and for application with fertilizers have already been 62
registered for use. These include soil applied AZteroid TM fungicide (azoxystrobin), soil 63
Page 3 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
4
applied Bifender TM insecticide (bifenthrin) and plant applied Fenstro TM insecticide 64 (azoxystrobin + bifenthrin). 8 It is expected that an increasing number of nano-enabled 65 pesticide products will be submitted to regulatory agencies for registration over the next five 66 years. 67 For the purposes of this perspectives article, a nano-enabled pesticide means a product 68 in which a nanomaterial has been used to enhance the functionality, utility and/or alter the 69 risk profile of a conventional a.i. 70

sections.heading: RISK ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORKS FOR NANO-ENABLED PESTICIDES 71
sections.text:
Ecological risk assessment of pesticide a.i.s and formulated products is a highly 72
developed process which forms an integral part of pesticide regulatory frameworks. 8-10 The 73 issues associated with assessing the ecological risks of nanomaterials within the conventional 74 risk-assessment paradigm used for chemicals and chemical products have been explored by 75
the OECD Working Party on Manufactured Nanomaterials. 11, 12 This work concluded that the 76 existing risk-assessment paradigm used for chemicals can be adapted to the risk assessment 77 of nanomaterials. 78 Problem formulation is a key initial phase in the ecological risk assessment of 79 chemicals. This phase of assessment is intended to define the nature of the problem to be 80 addressed by risk assessment and to develop a plan or strategy by which the risks can be 81 subsequently characterised. 13 The consistent and structured application of problem 82 formulation principles to the risk assessment of nano-enabled pesticide products will be 83 essential in formulating sound recommendations to risk managers and decision makers in 84 regulatory agencies. It will also help identify the most relevant assessment information 85 including hazard and exposure data, and available risk reduction measures at an early stage in 86 the risk assessment process. These are acknowledged to be key factors influencing the 87
Page 4 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
5
conduct of effective risk assessments. 14 88 In this perspectives article, we describe an approach to problem formulation using a case 89 study involving a hypothetical nano-enabled pesticide product. The approach taken is 90 intended to demonstrate how a practical assessment strategy would be developed using 91 principles adapted from the ecological risk assessment of conventional pesticide products. As 92 part of this strategy, an initial planning phase was conducted in which representatives from 93 key stakeholders including regulators, research scientists, and agrochemical scientists 94 collaborated to identify key issues that should be considered before the problem formulation 95 phase began. The key elements of this stage in the process are presented in the form of the 96 following questions: 97 ● What is the agronomic context for the use of the nano-enabled pesticide formulation? 98 ● What is the nature and purpose of the nanomaterial in the formulation? 99
● What are the ecological protection priorities that need to be considered in the risk 100 assessment of the nano-enabled pesticide formulation? 101 Following the collection of relevant information from the stakeholder group, the problem 102 formulation phase was undertaken focussing on another set of key questions: 103 ● How does the environmental behaviour of the nano-enabled pesticide differ from 104 conventional formulations of the same active ingredient? 105 ● How does the nanomaterial release the active ingredient in the environment? 106 ● What information is necessary to characterise the novel properties of the nano-enabled 107 pesticide formulation? 108 ● What risk reduction measures can be used to manage any environmental risks that are 109 considered possible from the intended use of the nano-enabled pesticide product? 110
Page 5 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
6
PENDIMETHALIN IN NANO-SIZED HYDROGELS – A CASE STUDY 111 Background information and agronomic context 112 Pendimethalin (CAS RN: 40487-42-1; benzeneamine, N-(1-ethylpropyl)-3,4-113 dimethyl-2,6-dinitro-, or N-(1-ethylpropyl)-2,6-dinitro-3,4-xylidene) is a dinitroaniline 114 herbicide that is absorbed through the roots and shoots. It is used to control annual grasses 115 and broadleaf weeds and is applied as a pre- or post-emergence spray. 15 Conventional 116 formulations of pendimethalin include aqueous capsule suspensions, granules, emulsifiable 117 concentrates, and liquid formulations, all of which will include surfactants and other 118 ingredients necessary for proper function of the formulation. Dry (granular) formulations will 119 also typically use an inorganic carrier that is impregnated with the a.i.. 120 Pendimethalin is a lipophilic neutral organic chemical (log KOW = 5.2) that is slightly 121 soluble in water (0.33 mg/L at 20 °C) and slightly volatile (0.0013 Pa at 25 °C). The Henry's 122 Law constant for the chemical (0.087 Pa-m 3 /mol) indicates that it is moderately volatile from 123 water and moist soil. The chemical adsorbs strongly to soil (KOC = 6,500 to 43,863 L/kg) and 124 pendimethalin is generally considered immobile in soil. Pendimethalin is slightly degradable 125 in aerobic soil and the reported half-life is in the range of 3 to 4 months. 15 126 Pendimethalin has high acute toxicity to aquatic life including fish, invertebrates, 127 algae, and aquatic plants. The chemical has moderate to high chronic toxicity to aquatic life 128 and is a bioaccumulation hazard in aquatic organisms based on the measured 129 bioconcentration factor in fish (BCF = 5100). The chemical has low to moderate toxicity to 130 non-target terrestrial organisms. 16 131 Description of the nano-enabled pesticide formulation and intended use 132 A realistic nano-enabled formulation was chosen to allow this “thought experiment” 133 to describe the process of problem formulation. This formulation is a simplified version of 134
Page 6 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
7
the technology developed by Vive Crop Protection. The hypothetical pendimethalin herbicide 135 product considered in this case study is a suspension concentrate (SC) formulation containing 136 20% by weight of a.i. and 5% by weight of lightly crosslinked polyacrylate polymer particles 137 which function as a nano-scale carrier for the a.i.. Polyacrylates are a broad class of 138 polymers; for this thought experiment, polyacrylates that are water-dispersible hydrogels with 139 both hydrophilic and hydrophobic monomers are considered. Formulations with 20% a.i. and 140 5% by weight polymer particles has been described previously [US patent 8741808]. The 141 specific chemistry of the hydrogel necessary to increase soil mobility does not significantly 142 impact the problem formulation provided in a later section. Therefore, for simplicity in this 143 thought experiment, as well as to protect confidential information of Vive Crop Protection, a 144 generic polyacrylate hydrogel was chosen as a model. The average size of the polyacrylate 145 nanocarriers is in the range of 5 to 20 nm. 146 The polyacrylate nanocarriers are hydrogels which are a class of materials that have 147 been investigated for delivery of many different poorly-soluble bioactive pharmaceuticals as 148
well as agrochemical molecules. 17-18 A hydrogel is able to absorb large amounts of water or 149 other fluids 17 and swell (as a result of crosslinks formed during synthesis), as opposed to 150 dissolving in an aqueous environment. The purpose of the polyacrylate hydrogel in this SC 151 formulation is to assist with dispersion of the a.i. in aqueous media (such as water in spray 152 tanks) and with a.i. mobility in soil. 18 153 Pendimethalin is loaded into the matrix of the hydrogel nanocarrier to form a 154 composite structure (the complex). This complex is a labile structure and is able to release the 155 a.i. in soil for uptake by plants. The overall properties of the complex are determined by the 156 hydrogel composition, the method and degree of crosslinking, a.i. loading, and the nature of 157
the environment in which the complex is deployed (dry, liquid, pH, etc.). 18-19 The formation 158
Page 7 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
8
of this complex has the net effect that the properties of the external portion of the nanocarrier 159 dominate the interaction with the environment for as long as the a.i. remains within the 160 matrix of the hydrogel particles. For the purposes of this article, we are considering a 161 complex where the hydrogel assists the pendimethalin to penetrate into soil, thereby 162 increasing the amount of a.i. that reaches sub-surface weeds. 163 This product will be applied as a pre-emergence herbicide at a maximum application 164 rate of 4 kg a.i./ha. The product is intended to penetrate through surface residue into the soil 165 without manual incorporation. It requires moderate rainfall or irrigation to be active against 166 target species. In moderate to heavy rains or irrigation, the applied a.i. is expected to 167 penetrate between 2.5 and 10 cm below the soil surface, with < 1% of applied a.i. penetrating 168 below 10 cm. This effect has been observed with a modified version of the polyacrylate 169 hydrogels described in this paper (Vive Crop Protection, Canada, Personal Communication). 170 Formulation benefits are similar to existing techniques for increasing soil penetration such as 171 soil conditioners or penetration aid surfactants. 172 For the purposes of this case study, it is assumed that the product will be applied by 173 ground spraying under conditions and using technology which minimises off-site movement 174 of the pesticide through spray drift. 175 Ecological protection priorities 176 The nano-enabled pendimethalin SC product considered here is intended to be applied 177 to a wide variety of agricultural crops for the control of annual grasses and weeds by ground 178 spray application at a rate of nearly 4 kilograms a.i. per hectare. Similar to conventional 179 pendimethalin herbicide products there is a potential risk to aquatic environments from the 180 off-site movement of the a.i. in the nano-enabled pesticide product because pendimethalin is 181 highly toxic to aquatic life and bioconcentrates in fish. The ecological risk assessment of the 182
Page 8 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
9
nano-enabled product will, therefore, need to establish that the proposed use pattern and 183 application rate will not result in levels of pendimethalin in aquatic ecosystems in excess of 184 the locally applicable water quality guideline values for this a.i. 185 PROBLEM FORMULATION 186 Pendimethalin is highly toxic to aquatic organisms and is also a bioaccumulation 187 hazard in aquatic ecosystems. The off-site movement of this active ingredient from its 188 application as a pre-emergence herbicide, which results in contamination of aquatic 189 ecosystems, may cause adverse effects on the natural environment. The ecological risk 190 assessment of the intended uses of the nano-enabled pendimethalin SC product will, 191 therefore, need to establish whether aquatic ecosystems will be adversely impacted by the a.i. 192 or any of the excipients in the product, including the polyacrylate nanocarrier. 193 Comparative evaluation of the nano-enabled pendimethalin formulation and 194 conventional formulations 195 One key difference between traditional surfactants (used in conventional 196 formulations) and the use of nano-scale hydrogel carriers is the durability of the complex in 197 diverse environments. Surfactant systems are sensitive to exposure conditions such as surface 198 interactions, pH, and concentration which may mean that the a.i.-surfactant complex is only 199 stable over a relatively narrow range of operating conditions. The inclusion of cross-links in a 200 hydrogel enables the nanocarrier complex to maintain its tertiary structure and retain its 201 integrity under a wider range of conditions. 20 202 Similar to previous studies, 21 the nanocarrier complex envisioned here would 203 facilitate the dispersion of this poorly water soluble herbicide in water without the use of 204 organic solvents and would also reduce the volatilization of the a.i. after application. These 205 two formulation characteristics have the potential to increase the amount of a.i. available for 206
Page 9 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
10
weed control and reduce the amount of a.i. lost off-site through atmospheric transport 207 processes. The complex would also enable the a.i. to penetrate the subsoil surface without the 208 need for physical incorporation such as tilling. 209 The nanocarrier is designed to enhance the soil penetration of pendimethalin. 210 Consequently, the potential key differences between this formulation and a conventional 211 formulation may include: penetration of pendimethalin into the subsoil water column; 212 reduced biological and chemical degradation of the a.i. leading to increased persistence; and a 213 reduction in off-site migration of the a.i. through volatilisation and other processes, such as 214 surface runoff. 215 Fate of the nano-enabled pesticide formulation in soil 216 The fate and behaviour of nano-enabled pesticides in the environment is likely to be 217 dependent on the functional characteristics of the carrier and the durability of the a.i.–carrier 218 complex. Both characteristics should be considered in problem formulation of nano-enabled 219 pesticides as the spatial and temporal nature of exposure to non-target organisms could 220 change significantly when compared to conventional pesticide formulations. 221 Durability is a measure of how long a pesticide-nanocarrier complex maintains its 222 integrity after application in the field. 22 The durability of pesticide-nanocarrier complexes can 223 be categorised into three broad classes as shown in Figure 1. 224 <Figure 1, here> 225 Durability is likely to be dependent on the exposure conditions. For example, a nano-226 enabled pesticide may release the a.i. at different rates in soil depending on factors, such as 227 soil moisture or soil pH. These will be important considerations for the risk assessment. 228 A conceptual model that can help identify the altered scenario of pesticide fate (mobility and 229 persistence) relative to the pure a.i., depending on the properties of the nano-carrier and 230
Page 10 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
11
pesticide a.i. in the new formulation, has been presented in Figure 2. The figure provides an 231 overview of the different combinations of nano-carrier and a.i. properties that are most 232 relevant for environmental exposure assessment of the a.i. (here it is assumed that the 233 exhausted nanocarrier is of low hazard, an assumption that may need to be verified in some 234 cases). 235 <Figure 2, here> 236 The most sensitive fate descriptors are expected to be: (i) the mobility of the 237 nanocarrier (Figure 2A, and 2B); (ii) the mobility and persistence of the a.i. (x-axis and z-axis 238
in Figure 2); and (iii) the rate at which the a.i. is released from the nanocarrier (y-axis). 4, 23 239 Distinguishing different combinations of nanocarrier and a.i. properties allows situations to 240 be identified where the impact on fate is likely to be minimal (flag “OK” in Figure 2), and 241 where particular attention to changes in the mobility (“M” flag) and/or persistence (“P” flag) 242 of the a.i. is required. 243 In cases where the release rate of the a.i. from the carrier is very fast compared to the 244 time scale of the environmental processes of interest (e.g. complete release occurs upon 245 dilution in the mixing tank or upon application in the field), no changes in the behaviour of 246 the nano-enabled a.i. formulation are to be expected compared to that of the pure a.i.. 247 Therefore, an exposure assessment solely based on data derived with the pure a.i. should be 248 adequate (indicated with the “OK” flag in Figure 2). 249 Conversely, when the nanocarriers and a.i. remain associated for a significant time, 250 effects of the formulation on the fate of the a.i. are to be expected in almost all cases. For 251 instance, for an a.i. that is not excessively persistent, association with a nanocarrier may 252 increase the persistence of the a.i. (“P” flag on Figure 2) as the availability of the a.i. for 253 degradation processes is likely to be reduced until it is released from the nanocarrier. The 254
Page 11 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
12
impact of the formulation on the transport of an a.i. in this case depends on the mobility of 255 the nanocarriers relative to that of the a.i.. Mobile carriers are likely to increase the mobility 256 of a relatively immobile a.i. (“+M” flag in Figure 2A), while relatively immobile nanocarriers 257 will decrease the mobility of a relatively mobile a.i. (“-M” flag in Figure 2B), which could 258 lead to greater exposure concentrations in the surface soil compartment for longer periods. 259 In the case study being considered here, the hydrogel is a mobile nanocarrier (Vive Crop 260 Protection; Personal communication). Therefore, Figure 2A will be the relevant scheme for 261 this formulation. The formulation is designed such that the a.i. remains encapsulated in the 262 mobile nanocarrier long enough to facilitate its entry into soil. The formulation is, therefore, 263 considered to be at least moderately durable and the upper plane in Figure 2 is relevant. 264 Pendimethalin is inherently a relatively immobile and moderately persistent herbicide, as 265 discussed above. Hence, the ultimate locus for the product will be at the low mobility end of 266 the x-axis and at the moderate persistence location on the z-axis, as shown in Figure 2A. 267 Hence, according to this conceptual scheme, +M/P is the most relevant flag, suggesting 268 possible increased mobility and persistence of the nano-enabled pendimethalin relative to the 269 pure a.i.. 270 However, as stated above, pendimethalin has a half-life in aerobic soil in the range of 271 3 to 4 months. The durability of the a.i.-nanocarrier complex is assumed to be on the time 272 scale of days in this case and the apparent increase in persistence of pendimethalin is, 273 therefore, not expected to be consequential. In other cases, where the durability of the a.i.-274 nanocarrier complex is comparable or greater than the persistence of the a.i., the overall 275 persistence of an a.i. could be significantly enhanced because the nanocarrier facilitates 276 penetration of the a.i. into the deeper subsoil, where lower microbial activity is expected. 277
Page 12 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
13
Key end points 278 An extensive set of aquatic toxicity data is available for pendimethalin that could be 279 used to characterise the ecological risks to aquatic ecosystems, where the magnitude and 280 frequency of exposure to the a.i. can be quantified. Similarly, the environmental fate and 281 behaviour of this a.i. in conventional herbicide products are well studied and the available 282 data are sufficient to allow models for environmental exposure to be developed. However, the 283 conceptual model for the nano-enabled formulation of pendimethalin has identified some 284 potentially significant modifications in the fate and behaviour of the a.i.. The significance of 285 these particular properties of the nano-enabled formulation will need to be considered during 286 the risk analysis and risk characterisation stage of the assessment. 287 The two most significant environmental fate characteristics identified for the nano-288 enabled formulation through the conceptual model are the depth of penetration of the a.i.-289 nanocarrier complex through the soil column, and the rate of release of the a.i. from the 290 carrier. The depth of penetration is expected to be unique to this particular formulation, as it 291 is a functional characteristic that has been engineered by selection of the particular 292 polyacrylate nanoparticles used as a carrier. Since the behaviour of the a.i.-polyacrylate 293 complex is dominated by the properties of the nanocarrier, it may be possible to use surrogate 294 information on the general soil penetration behaviour of polyacrylate nanoparticles with 295 similar size distributions, chemical structure, and surface characteristics. However, where no 296 reference data are available, or where the properties of the complex differ substantially from 297 the nanocarrier alone, a specific evaluation of the soil penetration depth for the complex may 298 be required. 299 The rate of release of the a.i. from the complex has also been identified as a key 300 environmental fate characteristic of the formulation, and needs to be considered during the 301
Page 13 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
14
risk analysis phase. If the rate of release of the a.i. from the carrier is slow compared to major 302 transport processes such as leaching or transport in surface water run-off, then the aquatic 303 environment may be exposed to pendimethalin in ways that are not well represented by 304 available ecotoxicity data. In an exposure scenario involving release of a mobile and 305 moderately durable a.i.–carrier complex into aquatic ecosystems, aquatic life may be exposed 306 to the a.i. for a longer period at lower concentrations, resulting from the slow release of the 307 a.i. from the carrier. Conversely, if the rate of release of the a.i. from the complex is fast 308 compared to these transport processes, the environmental fate and effects of the a.i. may be 309 indistinguishable from conventional formulations. It is for this reason that an early and 310 reliable measure of the durability of the nanocarrier complex under environmentally relevant 311 conditions would be considered a priority. 312 Risk reduction and risk management options 313 The focus of the risk assessment can be shaped by considering the available risk 314 reduction measures and their effectiveness in the problem formulation stage of the 315 assessment. 12 For the purposes of this assessment, it is assumed that good agricultural 316 practices will limit off-site movement of the pesticide following application. In addition, 317 since the nano-enabled product will only be applied by ground spraying using spray-drift 318 reduction technology there is a reduced potential for direct exposure of the aquatic 319 environment to the a.i.–nanocarrier complex. This reduces both the need to consider the risks 320 posed to the aquatic environment through slow release of the a.i. from the nanocarrier over an 321 extended timeframe and the likelihood that additional aquatic ecotoxicity data will be 322 required to determine the specific toxicity of the a.i.-nanocarrier complex. Conversely, if the 323 typical application pattern were to be broadened to include aerial application of the nano-324 enabled formulation then the scope of the assessment would need to include factors such as 325
Page 14 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
15
the spray drift distances of the nano-enabled formulation and the effectiveness of no-spray 326 buffer zones to mitigate impacts on aquatic ecosystems. 327 Analysis plan 328 The hypothetical nano-enabled pendimethalin SC product considered in this case 329 study does potentially pose risks to the aquatic environment where off-site movement of the 330 a.i. and/or the a.i.-nanocarrier complex occurs. A conceptual model for the fate and behaviour 331 of the a.i.-nanocarrier complex in soil has identified some potential for the a.i. to have 332 increased persistence in soil relative to conventional formulations of pendimethalin. The 333 model also shows a potential for increased depth of penetration of the a.i. through the soil 334 horizon because of transport of the more mobile polyacrylate nanoparticle carriers. There is, 335 therefore, an increased potential for pendimethalin to reach ground water compared to 336 conventional formulations. 337 A key priority for the risk analysis phase of the assessment is to establish the 338 durability of the a.i.-nanocarrier complex in soil. An understanding of this characteristic will 339 allow further decisions to be made regarding both exposure assessment and hazard 340 evaluation. The initial analysis of the ecological risks of the product will, therefore, focus on 341 evaluating any available data on the durability of the a.i.-nanocarrier complex in soil. Where 342 such data are lacking and no useful reference data can be identified, it may be necessary to 343 recommend targeted evaluation of the durability of the complex in soil. Once this key 344 property has been evaluated the problem formulation may need to be revised. For example, if 345 the complex is determined to be not durable on the timescale of applicable off-site transport 346 processes, then the risk analysis may be abbreviated as the risks of the nano-enabled product 347 would not be considered significantly different from conventional formulations of 348 pendimethalin. Conversely, if this initial evaluation demonstrates that the a.i.-nanocarrier 349
Page 15 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
16
complex is moderately durable in soil and the complex is significantly mobile in soil and 350 water then the risk analysis phase may need to consider the need for specific environmental 351 fate and effects data on the nano-enabled formulation. 352
PROBLEM FORMULATION IS AN ITERATIVE PROCESS 353 Problem formulation provides an important opportunity to properly define the scope 354 of a risk assessment and to integrate the needs of the risk managers and decision makers, who 355 ultimately decide how and when chemicals or chemical products can be safely introduced to 356 the marketplace. The approach outlined above is based around a series of general questions 357 that guide the process. The crucial step is to determine what information is necessary to 358 characterise the novel properties of the nano-enabled pesticide formulation. The use of 359 nanomaterials in formulations (such as nanocarriers) can significantly alter the fate of the 360 active ingredient in soil, and we describe a simple framework to help risk assessors determine 361 how the formulation is likely to affect mobility and persistence of the a.i., based on the 362 known persistence and mobility of the a.i. and the durability of the nano-enabled pesticide. 363 The problem formulation is guided by the nature of the product being assessed and 364 associated application scenario. The problem formulation presented here for the nano-enabled 365 pendimethalin SC herbicide product shows only the first iteration of the process. An 366 important feature of the problem formulation phase of risk assessment is iteration. 13 For 367 conventional chemicals and chemical products, the iterative cycle may be abbreviated 368 because there is a wealth of relevant experience that can be used when formulating the initial 369 risk assessment hypothesis. The major factors influencing the environmental fate and effects 370 of most major classes of chemical are well understood and the most important factors 371 influencing ecological risks have been established over decades of practice. However, for 372 unconventional chemicals and/or novel exposure scenarios there is often a need to revise the 373
Page 16 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
17
initial risk assessment hypotheses developed during the problem formulation phase, and to 374 revise the risk analysis plan accordingly. This iterative approach is also likely to be important 375 in regulatory assessment of nano-enabled pesticides as there are as yet few registered nano-376 enabled agrochemical products. 377

The authors acknowledge Dr 392 David Brittain (Department of the Environment and Energy, Australia) for assistance with 393 modelling of various scenarios for release of pesticides from nanocarriers, and for a critical 394 review of the manuscript. We are also thankful to the three anonymous reviewers for their 395 constructive comments on the manuscript. 396
397
Page 17 of 25
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
18

FIGURE CAPTIONS 493
Figure 1. Durability of nano-enabled pesticide with a core-shell structure: When a nano-494 enabled pesticide comprised of a carrier/encapsulation material (represented in green) and an 495 a.i. (represented in yellow) is applied in the field, environmental durability can vary widely. 496 This variation is depicted for rapid release, slow release, and no release of the a.i. from the 497 complex. A represents a scenario when the a.i. is released rapidly (e.g. within hours after 498 application); B represents a slower release (over several days) of a.i. and C, when a.i. is not 499 released (e.g. over several weeks) from the nanocarrier. 500
